awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Prices, Peers, and Perceptions: Field Experiments on Technology Adoption in the Context of Improved Cookstoves
awd_abstract_narration:
Adoption of potentially welfare-improving technologies remains frustratingly low in many contexts. Improved cookstoves are a prime example: while cleaner-burning stove technologies have potential health, environmental, and social benefits, efforts to disseminate these technologies have fallen short and the practice of cooking with biomass over open fires remains dominant throughout much of the developing world. The central aim of this proposal is to study how economic incentives ("prices"), social learning ("peers"), and subjective beliefs ("perceptions") interact to influence technology adoption dynamics. We do so through a field experiment that offers new stoves at different price levels to groups of households with and without social ties to households that have already received stoves. Our results will inform and future efforts to disseminate welfare-enhancing technologies to larger population groups.

Our conceptual model of households' technology adoption and use decisions highlights multiple potential interactions among prices, peers, and perceptions.  Key research questions that will be addressed through our experiments include how price affects perceived quality of a new technology, how these perceptions are modified by exposure to peers that have experience with the technology, and how perceptions change over time based on one's own experience and (objective and subjective) technology performance. We implement a novel identification strategy for identifying these effects, using the preexisting and exogenously controlled distribution of free stoves in combination with uncorrelated, cluster-randomized assignment to different stove subsidy levels. By explicitly measuring perceptions in conjunction with other outcome variables in the experiment (including both surveys and physical indicators of stove use and impacts on personal exposure to pollutants), the researchers will be able to test specific models about how prices and peers (prior adoption interact in belief formation) a key issue in the technology adoption literature.

por.por_cntn:
Worldwide, there are many technologies with large potential health and social benefits but persistently low rates of uptake and use. Improved cookstoves are a prime example: despite the potential for cleaner stoves to reduce household air pollution, improve human health, and mitigate climate change, the practice of cooking with inefficient biomass stoves remains widespread in many low- and middle-income countries. The central aim of the Prices, Peers, and Perceptions (P3) project was to study factors influencing adoption of improved cookstoves in Northern Ghana. Specifically, we examined how economic incentives (prices), social learning (peers), and subjective beliefs (perceptions) interact to influence technology adoption dynamics. This work involved field experiments in both rural and urban areas of the Kassena-Nankana Districts (KND), using both improved biomass and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) stoves.  


The P3 Bio study arm focused on improved biomass-burning stoves in the rural areas of the KND, leveraging an earlier NSF-funded project to implement a novel experimental design.  Specifically, we offered two types of improved biomass stoves at randomly assigned prices to peers and non-peers of households that had received similar stoves for free during the prior project. Through our interdisciplinary study design and data collection processes, we are able to identify the interactive effects of prices and peers on a range of key outcomes, including stove perceptions, initial stove orders and final purchases, stove use (via surveys and electronic stove use monitors), household air pollution, and personal exposure to pollutants. We find that:

  1. Price and peer effects vary across the two types of stoves that were offered. Demand for the higher-tech ACE1 stove is somewhat lower among peer-group households compared to non-peers, likely because the analogous stove that was distributed in the prior study experienced a high rate of battery failures and other technical issues. This highlights the potential for “market spoilage” effects, which can shape technology adoption dynamics over time.

  2. Households strongly prefer a combination of two different types of stoves: willingness to pay for the ACE1 + (lower tech) Greenway Jumbo bundle exceeds the sum of households’ willingness to pay for each stove by itself (and is equal to roughly three-fifths of the stoves’ total retail costs). Our economic experiment shows that the two stoves, rather than being perceived by households as substitutes, are highly complementary, likely because they can be used simultaneously, with different types of fuel, to cook different types of dishes. A combination or “cleaner stack” of stove options may thus be more effective to meet households’ energy needs and supplant traditional technologies.


Meanwhile, the P3 Gas study arm focused on measuring factors affecting demand for liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) stoves and fuel among households in the urban areas of the KND. We designed an LPG intervention around six different stove-fuel packages designed to address key barriers to LPG adoption identified through literature review and initial supply- and demand-side surveys. First, many households perceive that standard LPG stoves are not well suited to cooking some traditional meals, or to using large pots. We added a locally made single burner LPG stove which may be better suited to local cooking needs. Second, both the upfront cost of purchasing a stove and the recurring cost of fuel purchases can be significant barriers to LPG adoption and sustained use. Using a modified Becker-Degroot-Marshak (BDM) auction, our experiment assessed willingness to pay for each of these cost components. In addition, time costs of traveling to LPG refilling stations can be substantial. We therefore also included packages that included home delivery of stove refills. Our results indicate that participants were only willing to pay about a third of the value of the LPG fuel component of the packages while WTP for both types of stoves was very close to their market values. This suggests that the recurrent long term cost of purchasing LPG fuel is a more significant barrier to sustained use than the upfront cost of purchasing stoves.


Our results, and the relationships that we developed over the course of these studies, are likely to have broad reach beyond this specific project.  In both the P3 Bio and P3 Gas studies, our international and multi-institutional research team worked in collaboration with a local non-governmental organization and both local and international stove and fuel companies to design and implement the project, and to interpret and disseminate our results.  This collaborative structure enhances the potential that our findings will inform household energy policies in the study area and beyond.
